column2: the food was pretty good. I can't deny it.  The ramen was excellent.  The fried shrimp appetizer was fine.  The takoyaki (about which I was very excited) was under-cooked; the batter was raw inside.  But overall
column3: the food was just fine.  My problem was with the service.  A ramen house usually provides very attentive
column4: very friendly service.  The service at Jinya was disorganized and disinterested.  Other than the obligatory (and tepid) "irasshaimase" the staff seemed to have little interest in the diners.  That
column5: and the 15 minutes we waited to just order drinks cost the place two stars.
